Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Animated corpses appear
in stories all over the world throughout recorded history. But zombies have a distinct lineage— one that traces back 
to Equatorial and Central Africa. The first clue is in the word 
“zombie” itself. Its exact etymological origins 
are unknown, but there are several candidates. The Mitsogho people of Gabon, for example,
use the word “ndzumbi” for corpse. The Kikongo word “nzambi” refers
variously to the supreme being, an ancestor with superhuman abilities,
or another deity. And, in certain languages spoken
in Angola and the Congo, “zumbi” refers to an object inhabited 
by a spirit, or someone returned from the dead. There are also similarities
in certain cultural beliefs. For example, in Kongo tradition, 
it’s thought that once someone dies, their spirit can be housed 
in a physical object which might bring protection 
and good luck. Similar beliefs about what
might happen to someone’s soul after death are held 
in various parts of Africa. Between 1517 and 1804, France and Spain enslaved 
hundreds of thousands of African people, taking them to the Caribbean island that now contains Haiti 
and the Dominican Republic. There, the religious beliefs 
of enslaved African people mixed with the Catholic traditions 
of colonial authorities and a religion known as “vodou” developed. According to some vodou beliefs, a 
person’s soul can be captured and stored, becoming a body-less “zombi.” Alternatively, if a body isn’t properly
attended to soon after death, a sorcerer called a “bokor”
can capture a corpse and turn it into a soulless zombi
that will perform their bidding. Historically, these zombis were said 
to be put to work as laborers who needed neither food nor rest 
and would enrich their captor’s fortune. In other words, zombification seemed 
to represent the horrors of enslavement that many Haitian people experienced. It was the worst possible fate: a form of enslavement that not even
death could free you from. The zombi was deprived of an afterlife
and trapped in eternal subjugation. Because of this, in Haitian culture, zombis are commonly seen as victims
deserving of sympathy and care. The zombie underwent a transformation
after the US occupation of Haiti began in 1915— this time, through the lens
of Western pop culture. During the occupation, US citizens
propagated many racist beliefs about Black Haitian people. Among false accounts
of devil worship and human sacrifice, zombie stories captured
the American imagination. And in 1932, zombies debuted
on the big screen in a film called “White Zombie.” Set in Haiti, the film’s protagonist 
must rescue his fiancée from an evil vodou master who runs 
a sugar mill using zombi labor. Notably, the film's main object of
sympathy isn't the enslaved workforce, but the victimized white woman. Over the following decades, zombies
appeared in many American films, usually with loose references
to Haitian culture, though some veered off to involve
aliens and Nazis. Then came the wildly influential 1968 film
“Night of the Living Dead,” in which a group of strangers tries 
to survive an onslaught of slow-moving, flesh-eating monsters. The film’s director remarked that he never
envisioned his living dead as zombies. Instead, it was the audience who
recognized them as such. But from then on, zombies became linked
to an insatiable craving for flesh— with a particular taste for brains added
in 1985′s “The Return of the Living Dead.” In these and many subsequent films,
no sorcerer controls the zombies; they’re the monsters. And in many iterations, 
later fueled by 2002′s “28 Days Later,” zombification became 
a contagious phenomenon. For decades now, artists around the world
have used zombies to shine a light on the social ills 
and anxieties of their moment— from consumer culture to the global lack
of disaster preparedness. But, in effect, American pop culture also
initially erased the zombies origins— cannibalizing its original significance and transforming the victim 
into the monster.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When were many Africans enslaved by Europeans?
Options: A. 1000-1400, B. 1315-1600, C. 1517-1804, D. 1500-1776
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the origin of the word "zombie"? Options: A. The Kikongo word "nzambi" referring to the supreme being, B. The Mitsogho people's word "ndzumbi" for corpse, C. The English word "zombie" created in the 20th century, D. All of the above are possible origins Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to Kongo tradition, what happens to a person's spirit after death? Options: A. It is lost forever, B. It can be housed in a physical object for protection and good luck, C. It goes to heaven or hell, D. It is reincarnated Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the result of the mixing of African and Catholic traditions in the Caribbean? Options: A. The development of a new language, B. The creation of a new form of government, C. The development of the religion known as "vodou", D. The abolition of slavery Correct Option: C
Question 4: In Haitian culture, what is the common perception of zombis? Options: A. They are monstrous creatures that deserve to be feared, B. They are victims deserving of sympathy and care, C. They are supernatural beings with magical powers, D. They are a myth with no basis in reality Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the US occupation of Haiti influence the perception of zombies? Options: A. It led to a greater understanding of Haitian culture, B. It resulted in the transformation of zombies through the lens of Western pop culture, C. It had no impact on the perception of zombies, D. It led to the abolition of slavery in Haiti Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the main object of sympathy in the 1932 film "White Zombie"? Options: A. The enslaved workforce, B. The victimized white woman, C. The evil vodou master, D. The zombies themselves Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of the 1968 film "Night of the Living Dead" in the evolution of zombies in popular culture? Options: A. It introduced the concept of zombies as flesh-eating monsters, B. It linked zombies to an insatiable craving for brains, C. It was the first film to feature zombies as sympathetic characters, D. It was the first film to feature zombies as slow-moving creatures Correct Option: A
Question 8: How have artists used zombies in recent decades? Options: A. To shine a light on social ills and anxieties, B. To promote consumer culture, C. To glorify violence and gore, D. To ignore the zombie's origins Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the effect of American pop culture on the zombie's origins? Options: A. It preserved the zombie's original significance, B. It erased the zombie's origins and transformed the victim into the monster, C. It had no impact on the zombie's origins, D. It led to a greater understanding of Haitian culture Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about the evolution of zombies in popular culture? Options: A. It has remained faithful to the zombie's origins in Haitian culture, B. It has been influenced by a variety of cultural and historical factors, C. It has been driven solely by American pop culture, D. It has had no impact on society or culture Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly asking about the time period of enslavement. However, Question 3 mentions the result of the mixing of African and Catholic traditions in the Caribbean, which occurred during the time period of enslavement. 

A more relevant question would be one that explicitly mentions the time period. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the time period of enslavement. However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 3, as it is the closest in terms of historical context.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Animated corpses appear
in stories all over the world throughout recorded history. But zombies have a distinct lineage— one that traces back 
to Equatorial and Central Africa. The first clue is in the word 
“zombie” itself. Its exact etymological origins 
are unknown, but there are several candidates. The Mitsogho people of Gabon, for example,
use the word “ndzumbi” for corpse. The Kikongo word “nzambi” refers
variously to the supreme being, an ancestor with superhuman abilities,
or another deity. And, in certain languages spoken
in Angola and the Congo, “zumbi” refers to an object inhabited 
by a spirit, or someone returned from the dead. There are also similarities
in certain cultural beliefs. For example, in Kongo tradition, 
it’s thought that once someone dies, their spirit can be housed 
in a physical object which might bring protection 
and good luck. Similar beliefs about what
might happen to someone’s soul after death are held 
in various parts of Africa. Between 1517 and 1804, France and Spain enslaved 
hundreds of thousands of African people, taking them to the Caribbean island that now contains Haiti 
and the Dominican Republic. There, the religious beliefs 
of enslaved African people mixed with the Catholic traditions 
of colonial authorities and a religion known as “vodou” developed. According to some vodou beliefs, a 
person’s soul can be captured and stored, becoming a body-less “zombi.” Alternatively, if a body isn’t properly
attended to soon after death, a sorcerer called a “bokor”
can capture a corpse and turn it into a soulless zombi
that will perform their bidding. Historically, these zombis were said 
to be put to work as laborers who needed neither food nor rest 
and would enrich their captor’s fortune. In other words, zombification seemed 
to represent the horrors of enslavement that many Haitian people experienced. It was the worst possible fate: a form of enslavement that not even
death could free you from. The zombi was deprived of an afterlife
and trapped in eternal subjugation. Because of this, in Haitian culture, zombis are commonly seen as victims
deserving of sympathy and care. The zombie underwent a transformation
after the US occupation of Haiti began in 1915— this time, through the lens
of Western pop culture. During the occupation, US citizens
propagated many racist beliefs about Black Haitian people. Among false accounts
of devil worship and human sacrifice, zombie stories captured
the American imagination. And in 1932, zombies debuted
on the big screen in a film called “White Zombie.” Set in Haiti, the film’s protagonist 
must rescue his fiancée from an evil vodou master who runs 
a sugar mill using zombi labor. Notably, the film's main object of
sympathy isn't the enslaved workforce, but the victimized white woman. Over the following decades, zombies
appeared in many American films, usually with loose references
to Haitian culture, though some veered off to involve
aliens and Nazis. Then came the wildly influential 1968 film
“Night of the Living Dead,” in which a group of strangers tries 
to survive an onslaught of slow-moving, flesh-eating monsters. The film’s director remarked that he never

to an insatiable craving for flesh— with a particular taste for brains added
in 1985′s “The Return of the Living Dead.” In these and many subsequent films,

a contagious phenomenon. For decades now, artists around the world
have used zombies to shine a light on the social ills 
and anxieties of their moment— from consumer culture to the global lack
of disaster preparedness. But, in effect, American pop culture also
initially erased the zombies origins— cannibalizing its original significance and transforming the victim 
into the monster.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did zombification remind Haitians of?
Options: A. Mortality, B. Brains, C. Horror, D. Slavery
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the origin of the word "zombie"? Options: A. The Kikongo word "nzambi" referring to the supreme being, B. The Mitsogho people's word "ndzumbi" for corpse, C. The English word "zombie" created in the 20th century, D. All of the above are possible origins Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to Kongo tradition, what happens to a person's spirit after death? Options: A. It is lost forever, B. It can be housed in a physical object for protection and good luck, C. It goes to heaven or hell, D. It is reincarnated Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the result of the mixing of African and Catholic traditions in the Caribbean? Options: A. The development of a new language, B. The creation of a new form of government, C. The development of the religion known as "vodou", D. The abolition of slavery Correct Option: C
Question 4: In Haitian culture, what is the common perception of zombis? Options: A. They are monstrous creatures that deserve to be feared, B. They are victims deserving of sympathy and care, C. They are supernatural beings with magical powers, D. They are a myth with no basis in reality Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the US occupation of Haiti influence the perception of zombies? Options: A. It led to a greater understanding of Haitian culture, B. It resulted in the transformation of zombies through the lens of Western pop culture, C. It had no impact on the perception of zombies, D. It led to the abolition of slavery in Haiti Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the main object of sympathy in the 1932 film "White Zombie"? Options: A. The enslaved workforce, B. The victimized white woman, C. The evil vodou master, D. The zombies themselves Correct Option: B

It introduced the concept of zombies as flesh-eating monsters, B. It linked zombies to an insatiable craving for brains, C. It was the first film to feature zombies as sympathetic characters, D. It was the first film to feature zombies as slow-moving creatures Correct Option: A
Question 8: How have artists used zombies in recent decades? Options: A. To shine a light on social ills and anxieties, B. To promote consumer culture, C. To glorify violence and gore, D. To ignore the zombie's origins Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the effect of American pop culture on the zombie's origins? Options: A. It preserved the zombie's original significance, B. It erased the zombie's origins and transformed the victim into the monster, C. It had no impact on the zombie's origins, D. It led to a greater understanding of Haitian culture Correct Option: B

It has been influenced by a variety of cultural and historical factors, C. It has been driven solely by American pop culture, D. It has had no impact on society or culture Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Animated corpses appear
in stories all over the world throughout recorded history. But zombies have a distinct lineage— one that traces back 
to Equatorial and Central Africa. The first clue is in the word 
“zombie” itself. Its exact etymological origins 
are unknown, but there are several candidates. The Mitsogho people of Gabon, for example,
use the word “ndzumbi” for corpse. The Kikongo word “nzambi” refers
variously to the supreme being, an ancestor with superhuman abilities,
or another deity. And, in certain languages spoken
in Angola and the Congo, “zumbi” refers to an object inhabited 
by a spirit, or someone returned from the dead. There are also similarities
in certain cultural beliefs. For example, in Kongo tradition, 
it’s thought that once someone dies, their spirit can be housed 
in a physical object which might bring protection 
and good luck. Similar beliefs about what
might happen to someone’s soul after death are held 
in various parts of Africa. Between 1517 and 1804, France and Spain enslaved 
hundreds of thousands of African people, taking them to the Caribbean island that now contains Haiti 
and the Dominican Republic. There, the religious beliefs 
of enslaved African people mixed with the Catholic traditions 
of colonial authorities and a religion known as “vodou” developed. According to some vodou beliefs, a 
person’s soul can be captured and stored, becoming a body-less “zombi.” Alternatively, if a body isn’t properly
attended to soon after death, a sorcerer called a “bokor”
can capture a corpse and turn it into a soulless zombi
that will perform their bidding. Historically, these zombis were said 
to be put to work as laborers who needed neither food nor rest 
and would enrich their captor’s fortune. In other words, zombification seemed 
to represent the horrors of enslavement that many Haitian people experienced. It was the worst possible fate: a form of enslavement that not even
death could free you from. The zombi was deprived of an afterlife
and trapped in eternal subjugation. Because of this, in Haitian culture, zombis are commonly seen as victims
deserving of sympathy and care. The zombie underwent a transformation
after the US occupation of Haiti began in 1915— this time, through the lens
of Western pop culture. During the occupation, US citizens
propagated many racist beliefs about Black Haitian people. Among false accounts
of devil worship and human sacrifice, zombie stories captured
the American imagination. And in 1932, zombies debuted
on the big screen in a film called “White Zombie.” Set in Haiti, the film’s protagonist 
must rescue his fiancée from an evil vodou master who runs 
a sugar mill using zombi labor. Notably, the film's main object of
sympathy isn't the enslaved workforce, but the victimized white woman. Over the following decades, zombies
appeared in many American films, usually with loose references
to Haitian culture, though some veered off to involve
aliens and Nazis. Then came the wildly influential 1968 film
“Night of the Living Dead,” in which a group of strangers tries 
to survive an onslaught of slow-moving, flesh-eating monsters. The film’s director remarked that he never
envisioned his living dead as zombies. Instead, it was the audience who
recognized them as such. But from then on, zombies became linked
to an insatiable craving for flesh— with a particular taste for brains added
in 1985′s “The Return of the Living Dead.” In these and many subsequent films,
no sorcerer controls the zombies; they’re the monsters. And in many iterations, 
later fueled by 2002′s “28 Days Later,” zombification became 
a contagious phenomenon. For decades now, artists around the world
have used zombies to shine a light on the social ills 
and anxieties of their moment— from consumer culture to the global lack
of disaster preparedness. But, in effect, American pop culture also
initially erased the zombies origins— cannibalizing its original significance and transforming the victim 
into the monster.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When did the US occupation of Haiti begin?
Options: A. 1778, B. 1804, C. 1915, D. 1968
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Animated corpses appear
in stories all over the world throughout recorded history. But zombies have a distinct lineage— one that traces back 
to Equatorial and Central Africa. The first clue is in the word 
“zombie” itself. Its exact etymological origins 
are unknown, but there are several candidates. The Mitsogho people of Gabon, for example,
use the word “ndzumbi” for corpse. The Kikongo word “nzambi” refers
variously to the supreme being, an ancestor with superhuman abilities,
or another deity. And, in certain languages spoken
in Angola and the Congo, “zumbi” refers to an object inhabited 
by a spirit, or someone returned from the dead. There are also similarities
in certain cultural beliefs. For example, in Kongo tradition, 
it’s thought that once someone dies, their spirit can be housed 
in a physical object which might bring protection 
and good luck. Similar beliefs about what
might happen to someone’s soul after death are held 
in various parts of Africa. Between 1517 and 1804, France and Spain enslaved 
hundreds of thousands of African people, taking them to the Caribbean island that now contains Haiti 
and the Dominican Republic. There, the religious beliefs 
of enslaved African people mixed with the Catholic traditions 
of colonial authorities and a religion known as “vodou” developed. According to some vodou beliefs, a 
person’s soul can be captured and stored, becoming a body-less “zombi.” Alternatively, if a body isn’t properly
attended to soon after death, a sorcerer called a “bokor”
can capture a corpse and turn it into a soulless zombi
that will perform their bidding. Historically, these zombis were said 
to be put to work as laborers who needed neither food nor rest 
and would enrich their captor’s fortune. In other words, zombification seemed 
to represent the horrors of enslavement that many Haitian people experienced. It was the worst possible fate: a form of enslavement that not even
death could free you from. The zombi was deprived of an afterlife
and trapped in eternal subjugation. Because of this, in Haitian culture, zombis are commonly seen as victims
deserving of sympathy and care. The zombie underwent a transformation
after the US occupation of Haiti began in 1915— this time, through the lens
of Western pop culture. During the occupation, US citizens
propagated many racist beliefs about Black Haitian people. Among false accounts
of devil worship and human sacrifice, zombie stories captured
the American imagination. And in 1932, zombies debuted
on the big screen in a film called “White Zombie.” Set in Haiti, the film’s protagonist 
must rescue his fiancée from an evil vodou master who runs 
a sugar mill using zombi labor. Notably, the film's main object of
sympathy isn't the enslaved workforce, but the victimized white woman. Over the following decades, zombies
appeared in many American films, usually with loose references
to Haitian culture, though some veered off to involve
aliens and Nazis. Then came the wildly influential 1968 film
“Night of the Living Dead,” in which a group of strangers tries 
to survive an onslaught of slow-moving, flesh-eating monsters. The film’s director remarked that he never
envisioned his living dead as zombies. Instead, it was the audience who
recognized them as such. But from then on, zombies became linked
to an insatiable craving for flesh— with a particular taste for brains added
in 1985′s “The Return of the Living Dead.” In these and many subsequent films,
no sorcerer controls the zombies; they’re the monsters. And in many iterations, 
later fueled by 2002′s “28 Days Later,” zombification became 
a contagious phenomenon. For decades now, artists around the world
have used zombies to shine a light on the social ills 
and anxieties of their moment— from consumer culture to the global lack
of disaster preparedness. But, in effect, American pop culture also
initially erased the zombies origins— cannibalizing its original significance and transforming the victim 
into the monster.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What movie introduced the idea that zombies eat brains?
Options: A. Return of the Living Dead, B. Night of the Living Dead, C. King of the Zombies, D. Plan 9 from Outer Space
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Queen Liliʻuokalani ascended the throne after the death of her brother. What was his name?
Options: A. Kalākaua, B. Kamehameha, C. Lunalilo, D. Liholiho
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Lili'uokalani, and what was her role in Hawaiian history? Options: A. An American missionary who arrived in Hawaii in 1820, B. A member of the ali'i family who became Queen of Hawaii, C. A leader of the Missionary Party that plotted to annex Hawaii, D. A US Marine who participated in the coup against the Queen Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for the American missionaries' interest in Hawaii, and how did they amass power? Options: A. They sought to spread Christianity and built churches and schools, B. They wanted to establish a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, C. They were attracted by business opportunities, such as exporting sugar to the US tariff-free, D. They aimed to annex Hawaii and bring it under US control from the start Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of the Bayonet Constitution, and how did it affect Native Hawaiians? Options: A. It granted Native Hawaiians more rights and increased the monarchy's power, B. It stripped Native Hawaiians of their rights, diminished the monarchy's power, and ceded control to white businessmen, C. It established Hawaii as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, D. It had no impact on Native Hawaiians or the monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's response to the Bayonet Constitution, and what actions did she take to restore power to her people? Options: A. She accepted the constitution and worked with the Missionary Party, B. She authored a new constitution to restore power to Native Hawaiians, C. She staged a coup against the Missionary Party, D. She did nothing and allowed the situation to continue Correct Option: B
Question 5: What event occurred on January 17th, 1893, and how did it affect Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, B. The Committee of Safety staged a coup, and US Marines removed the Queen from office, C. The Hawaiian people protested against the Missionary Party, D. The Queen was imprisoned in the palace Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the alleged "Provisional Government," and what did it declare Hawaii to be the following year? Options: A. A constitutional monarchy with Queen Lili'uokalani as the ruler, B. A republic with a new oath of allegiance required for voting and government employment, C. A US territory with President William McKinley as the leader, D. A sovereign kingdom with a new constitution Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Queen Lili'uokalani's supporters respond to the Republic's brutal suppression of the counterrevolution, and what was the outcome? Options: A. They gave up and accepted the Republic's rule, B. They continued to fight, and the Republic eventually released the imprisoned supporters, C. They convinced Congress to halt the annexation treaty, D. They were all imprisoned or sentenced to death Correct Option: C
Question 8: What event in 1898 led to President William McKinley declaring Hawaii a US territory, and what was the impact on Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Spanish-American War began, and Hawaii was seen as a strategic military base, B. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, C. The Committee of Safety staged another coup, D. The Hawaiian people protested against the US annexation Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's legacy, and how did she continue to fight for her people's rights? Options: A. She gave up and accepted the US annexation, B. She continued to petition for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, and national liberation, C. She became a US citizen and supported the US government, D. She was forgotten by the Hawaiian people Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the significance of Queen Lili'uokalani's statement, "It is for them that I would give the last drop of my blood," and what did it reflect about her commitment to her people? Options: A. It showed her willingness to give up and accept the US annexation, B. It demonstrated her commitment to the US government and its interests, C. It reflected her love and dedication to the Hawaiian people, particularly the children, D. It was a statement of defeat and hopelessness Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the name of Queen Lili'uokalani's brother, who was the previous ruler of Hawaii. While none of the generated MCQs ask this specific question, Question 1 mentions Lili'uokalani's role in Hawaiian history and her membership in the ali'i family.

Although it's not a direct match, I would suggest Question 1 as the most similar generated MCQ, as it provides some context about Lili'uokalani's background and family. However, please note that the question intent and options are not identical to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: American missionaries arrived in Hawaiʻi in:
Options: A. 1846, B. 1820, C. 1805, D. 1888
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Lili'uokalani, and what was her role in Hawaiian history? Options: A. An American missionary who arrived in Hawaii in 1820, B. A member of the ali'i family who became Queen of Hawaii, C. A leader of the Missionary Party that plotted to annex Hawaii, D. A US Marine who participated in the coup against the Queen Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for the American missionaries' interest in Hawaii, and how did they amass power? Options: A. They sought to spread Christianity and built churches and schools, B. They wanted to establish a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, C. They were attracted by business opportunities, such as exporting sugar to the US tariff-free, D. They aimed to annex Hawaii and bring it under US control from the start Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of the Bayonet Constitution, and how did it affect Native Hawaiians? Options: A. It granted Native Hawaiians more rights and increased the monarchy's power, B. It stripped Native Hawaiians of their rights, diminished the monarchy's power, and ceded control to white businessmen, C. It established Hawaii as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, D. It had no impact on Native Hawaiians or the monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's response to the Bayonet Constitution, and what actions did she take to restore power to her people? Options: A. She accepted the constitution and worked with the Missionary Party, B. She authored a new constitution to restore power to Native Hawaiians, C. She staged a coup against the Missionary Party, D. She did nothing and allowed the situation to continue Correct Option: B
Question 5: What event occurred on January 17th, 1893, and how did it affect Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, B. The Committee of Safety staged a coup, and US Marines removed the Queen from office, C. The Hawaiian people protested against the Missionary Party, D. The Queen was imprisoned in the palace Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the alleged "Provisional Government," and what did it declare Hawaii to be the following year? Options: A. A constitutional monarchy with Queen Lili'uokalani as the ruler, B. A republic with a new oath of allegiance required for voting and government employment, C. A US territory with President William McKinley as the leader, D. A sovereign kingdom with a new constitution Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Queen Lili'uokalani's supporters respond to the Republic's brutal suppression of the counterrevolution, and what was the outcome? Options: A. They gave up and accepted the Republic's rule, B. They continued to fight, and the Republic eventually released the imprisoned supporters, C. They convinced Congress to halt the annexation treaty, D. They were all imprisoned or sentenced to death Correct Option: C
Question 8: What event in 1898 led to President William McKinley declaring Hawaii a US territory, and what was the impact on Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Spanish-American War began, and Hawaii was seen as a strategic military base, B. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, C. The Committee of Safety staged another coup, D. The Hawaiian people protested against the US annexation Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's legacy, and how did she continue to fight for her people's rights? Options: A. She gave up and accepted the US annexation, B. She continued to petition for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, and national liberation, C. She became a US citizen and supported the US government, D. She was forgotten by the Hawaiian people Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the significance of Queen Lili'uokalani's statement, "It is for them that I would give the last drop of my blood," and what did it reflect about her commitment to her people? Options: A. It showed her willingness to give up and accept the US annexation, B. It demonstrated her commitment to the US government and its interests, C. It reflected her love and dedication to the Hawaiian people, particularly the children, D. It was a statement of defeat and hopelessness Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Bayonet Constitution:
Options: A. Took away the monarch’s power, B. Took away voting rights for many native Hawaiians, C. Was enacted by force, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Committee of Safety joined forces, with U.S. diplomat John L. Stevens and a show of force by the U.S. marines aboard the U.S.S. Boston, to overthrow the Queen because she
Options: A. Wanted to sign a new constitution, B. Refused to sign another treaty with the U.S., C. Visited Great Britain, D. Wanted more ships to dock in Honolulu Harbor
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long was Queen Liliʻuokalani imprisoned in ʻIolani Palace?
Options: A. 2 years, B. 4 months, C. 8 months , D. 10 months
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Lili'uokalani, and what was her role in Hawaiian history? Options: A. An American missionary who arrived in Hawaii in 1820, B. A member of the ali'i family who became Queen of Hawaii, C. A leader of the Missionary Party that plotted to annex Hawaii, D. A US Marine who participated in the coup against the Queen Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for the American missionaries' interest in Hawaii, and how did they amass power? Options: A. They sought to spread Christianity and built churches and schools, B. They wanted to establish a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, C. They were attracted by business opportunities, such as exporting sugar to the US tariff-free, D. They aimed to annex Hawaii and bring it under US control from the start Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of the Bayonet Constitution, and how did it affect Native Hawaiians? Options: A. It granted Native Hawaiians more rights and increased the monarchy's power, B. It stripped Native Hawaiians of their rights, diminished the monarchy's power, and ceded control to white businessmen, C. It established Hawaii as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy, D. It had no impact on Native Hawaiians or the monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's response to the Bayonet Constitution, and what actions did she take to restore power to her people? Options: A. She accepted the constitution and worked with the Missionary Party, B. She authored a new constitution to restore power to Native Hawaiians, C. She staged a coup against the Missionary Party, D. She did nothing and allowed the situation to continue Correct Option: B
Question 5: What event occurred on January 17th, 1893, and how did it affect Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, B. The Committee of Safety staged a coup, and US Marines removed the Queen from office, C. The Hawaiian people protested against the Missionary Party, D. The Queen was imprisoned in the palace Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the alleged "Provisional Government," and what did it declare Hawaii to be the following year? Options: A. A constitutional monarchy with Queen Lili'uokalani as the ruler, B. A republic with a new oath of allegiance required for voting and government employment, C. A US territory with President William McKinley as the leader, D. A sovereign kingdom with a new constitution Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Queen Lili'uokalani's supporters respond to the Republic's brutal suppression of the counterrevolution, and what was the outcome? Options: A. They gave up and accepted the Republic's rule, B. They continued to fight, and the Republic eventually released the imprisoned supporters, C. They convinced Congress to halt the annexation treaty, D. They were all imprisoned or sentenced to death Correct Option: C
Question 8: What event in 1898 led to President William McKinley declaring Hawaii a US territory, and what was the impact on Queen Lili'uokalani and the Hawaiian people? Options: A. The Spanish-American War began, and Hawaii was seen as a strategic military base, B. The Queen introduced her new constitution, and it was widely accepted, C. The Committee of Safety staged another coup, D. The Hawaiian people protested against the US annexation Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was Queen Lili'uokalani's legacy, and how did she continue to fight for her people's rights? Options: A. She gave up and accepted the US annexation, B. She continued to petition for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, and national liberation, C. She became a US citizen and supported the US government, D. She was forgotten by the Hawaiian people Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the significance of Queen Lili'uokalani's statement, "It is for them that I would give the last drop of my blood," and what did it reflect about her commitment to her people? Options: A. It showed her willingness to give up and accept the US annexation, B. It demonstrated her commitment to the US government and its interests, C. It reflected her love and dedication to the Hawaiian people, particularly the children, D. It was a statement of defeat and hopelessness Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When Queen Liliʻuokalani was jailed, she passed her time by
Options: A. Making a patchwork quilt, B. Writing songs, C. Reading newspapers, brought to her wrapped around flowers from her garden, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”
